description.plain:
Lil' Kim (born Kimberly Denise Jones on July 11, 1974) grew up in Brooklyn, New York, living much of her adolescent life on the streets after being expelled from home.

Sometime between then and her super-stardom, she performed a freestyle rap for The Notorious B.I.G.. This got her music career started in 1995, as Biggie’s group Junior M.A.F.I.A., whose debut album Conspiracy generated three hit singles, two of which contained verses from Lil Kim (“I Need You Tonight” and “I Get Money”).

Lil' Kim’s debut studio album Hard Core (1996) earned Double Platinum status and spawned three consecutive #1 rap hits: “No Time”, “Not Tonight (Ladies Night Remix)”, and “Crush on You”, a record for a female rapper. Her following albums, The Notorious K.I.M. (2000) and La Bella Mafia (2003), were certified Platinum, making her the only female rapper besides Missy Elliott to have at least 3 platinum albums.

She was featured on the single, “Lady Marmalade”, which also had guest vocals by fellow recording artists Mya, Pink and Christina Aguilera (a remake of the 1975 smash hit, originally recorded by Patti LaBelle) which went to #1 on Billboard’s Hot 100, making her the first female rapper to have a #1 on that chart. In addition, the remake won two MTV Video Music Awards including Video of the Year, and a Grammy Award for Best Pop Collaboration with Vocals at the 44th Grammy Awards in 2002.

In 2005, she served a year-long prison sentence for lying to a jury about her friends' involvement in a shooting four years earlier. During her incarceration, her fourth album The Naked Truth was released. She returned to the public eye in 2009 with an appearance on Dancing with the Stars. Parting ways with major labels, she remained independent in the coming years, issuing a handful of mixtapes and branching out to other creative projects. After over a decade, her fifth studio full-length album 9 materialized in 2019.

With her hardcore posturing and sexually explicit rhymes, Lil' Kim is considered a hip-hop legend for blazing a trail for other like-minded and liberated female artists in the ‘90s and beyond. Aside from music, she is also known for her risk-taking and luxurious approach to fashion that influenced many, being often cited as a fashion icon. Throughout her life and career, the original Queen Bee has been noted for inspiring and helping others embrace their sexuality and individuality.

description.plain:
Lil Kim appears on this remix to “Crush On You,” which was released as a single to radio and used in the music video after the album version only features Lil' Cease on all three verses.

Lil Kim provided background information about the track:

I do remember being pregnant at the end of that album, where I couldn’t really finish some of the songs and that’s how Lil’ Cease ended up on “Crush on You.” He wasn’t supposed to be on that record, but I was sick and I had to go away and clear my head because I was pregnant. I wanted to finish the album because that’s what I wanted. I really wanted to display my talent to the world.

“Crush On You” samples the 1979 song “Rain Dance” by The Jeff Lorber Fusion:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wNqfnZ24pSg

description.plain:
Featured as a bonus track on Lil' Kim’s debut album Hardcore and the Nothing To Lose soundtrack, this track reached number 6 on  the Billboard Hot 100 and contains samples of Kool & The Gang’s “Ladies Night” and “We Are Family” by Sister Sledge.

It serves as an anthem of unity between the prominent female rappers of the ‘90s, in contrast to the state of female rap today.

Lil Kim talked about the origin and impact of the track:

That was actually Un’s idea, Lance Rivera [Former CEO/President of Undeas Records]. He always loved the “Ladies’ Night” thing. He had this idea where he thought we should have Angie Martinez on it because she was ruling the radio at the time and she wanted to rap. We loved the whole idea of lady empowerment. I just wanted all my favorite artists on it. TLC, Missy, Da Brat. That song landed us MTV nominations and Grammy nominations. So we did something right.

songs.full_title: Queen Bitch by Lil' Kim
songs.title: Queen Bitch

description.plain:
Perhaps Lil Kim’s most strong delivery on the whole Hard Core album, this song raised the bar for lyrics in the female hip-hop game. The Notorious B.I.G. provided the reference track to show her how to execute the song to the fullest. https://youtu.be/avrmrGsE6IY

This song was later sampled in Mary J. Blige’s “I Can Love You” featuring none other than Lil' Kim. A part two of the song was made with the assistance of Puff Daddy featured on Lil' Kim’s sophomore effort The Notorious K.I.M

songs.full_title: Big Momma Thang by Lil' Kim (Ft. JAY-Z & Lil' Cease)
songs.title: Big Momma Thang
songs.title_with_featured: Big Momma Thang (Ft. JAY-Z & Lil' Cease)

description.plain:
Based around a sample of Sylvester’s “Was It Something I Said?,” Lil Kim drops some dirty, hardcore rhymes while Jay-Z talks about hooking up with Kim in the recording studio.

The title of the song pays homage to Big Daddy Kane’s second album It’s a Big Daddy Thing. The same Sylvester sample was used on Big Daddy Kane’s 1990 single “Taste of Chocolate,” which features a cameo from Jay-Z in the music video.

Lil' Kim provided some background information about the track:

It was actually a diss record and then it was a couple things they wanted to change but couldn’t clear. A situation had happened at the time, so we put Jay-Z on it because the second verse was crazy. The record had leaked before the album came out, and then when a record leaked, it wasn’t really a good thing. It wasn’t a bad thing because the world would go crazy, but it wasn’t a good thing as far as financial sales for the record company.

songs.full_title: How Many Licks? by Lil' Kim (Ft. SisQó)
songs.title: How Many Licks?

description.plain:
“How Many Licks?” is the second single off of Lil' Kim’s sophomore studio album Notorious K.I.M. album, released in 2000 via Atlantic Records.

Written by Kim and Sisqó and produced by Mario Winans and Sean ‘Puff Daddy’ Combs, the hip hop song samples the Knight Rider theme song, while its chorus is a reference to the advertising slogan for Tootsie Pops.

An official remix of the song by American production duo The Neptunes was also included in the physical copies of the single with vocals by American singer Kelis and additional verses by American rappers Lil' Cease and Snoop Dogg.

The music video directed by Francis Lawrence features Kim as a plastic doll in three sexual fantasies. Sisqó did not appear in the video due to conflicts with his record label, Def Jam.

songs.full_title: Magic Stick by Lil' Kim (Ft. 50 Cent)
songs.title: Magic Stick

description.plain:
“Magic Stick” is a song performed by American hip hop and rap artist Lil' Kim, released as the second promotional single from her third studio album, La Bella Mafia. The single was an instant success, peaking at number two on the Billboard Hot 100 chart. The song marks Lil Kim’s highest charting single as a lead artist to date.

The song was originally intended for 50 Cent with Trina as a guest vocalist, but 50 Cent did not end up using Trina’s verses, and instead, had Lil Kim featured on the song.

songs.full_title: No Time by Lil' Kim (Ft. Diddy)
songs.title: No Time

description.plain: Lil Kim formally introduced herself to the world on October 29, 1996 with “No Time,” the first single off of her debut album Hard Core. The track, featuring P. Diddy, shot to the top of the charts where it peaked on the US Rap Songs charts at No. 1 for nine weeks. “No Time” features Diddy on the hook, singing about sipping Cristal and spreading love, while Kim’s introduction was a precursor to the perfected raunchy lyrics that she weaved throughout nearly every single one of her tracks. Between her repping the crew and simultaneously bragging about her sex life on lines, “No Time” landed her at the forefront of female MCs. The visuals that followed the release of the single were filmed in the World Trade Center with the two artists rapping while riding up and down elevators—a scene she would reference on two singles in the future.

songs.full_title: Lighters Up by Lil' Kim
songs.title: Lighters Up

description.plain:
Written by Lil Kim herself, “Lighters Up” is a “guide” from Kim letting people know what and what not to do in some parts of Brooklyn and how it runs on a daily basis.

The single was released on August 31, 2005, a few weeks before the release of her fourth album, The Naked Truth. “Lighters Up” was the first released single off The Naked Truth which created hype for the release of Kim’s album. It debuted at number 100 on the Billboard Top 100 and then rose to number 31 which then became her highest charting solo hit.

‘'Lighters Up’‘ was certified Platinum by the Recording Industry Association of America (RIAA) and sold up to 1,293,000 copies in the US alone!

songs.full_title: Drugs by Lil' Kim (Ft. The Notorious B.I.G.)
songs.title: Drugs

description.plain:
Hanging out with her marijuana-loving mentor, The Notorious B.I.G. and his Junior Mafia cronies surely gave Brooklyn queen Lil' Kim more contact highs than she could possibly remember. But instead of talking about her own weed passages on this standout track from her classic indelible debut disc “Hard Core”, she spits smack about jewels, furs, cars, liquor and sex.

It’s not until Big tells her how addicted he is to the beauty and the booty, that the “Drugs” are delivered. Biggie grunts, blowing blunt smoke in the air. Though producer, Fabian Hamilton, never became a household name, his work on “Drugs” were addictive.

songs.full_title: Crush on You by Lil' Kim (Ft. Lil' Cease & The Notorious B.I.G.)
songs.title: Crush on You
songs.title_with_featured: Crush on You (Ft. Lil' Cease & The Notorious B.I.G.)

description.plain:
This is the album version of “Crush On You”, with Lil' Cease on all three verses. The more popular remix version includes Lil' Kim.

Lil Kim provided background information about the track:

I do remember being pregnant at the end of that album, where I couldn’t really finish some of the songs and that’s how Lil’ Cease ended up on “Crush on You.” He wasn’t supposed to be on that record, but I was sick and I had to go away and clear my head because I was pregnant. I wanted to finish the album because that’s what I wanted. I really wanted to display my talent to the world.

Via XXL, Cam'ron claims to have written Cease’s verses:

What happened was, [Untertainment CEO Lance] Un [Rivera] gave Mase $30,000 to write five songs for Lil’ Cease at that time and Mase gave me $5,000 of the 30 to write one or two of the songs. I wrote the “Crush on You” song and they ended up keeping it for Lil’ Kim album but it was really for Lil’ Cease. The original “Crush on You” is all Lil’ Cease, Lil’ Kim isn’t even on the record.

“Crush On You” samples the The Jeff Lorber Fusion’s 1979 song “Rain Dance”:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wNqfnZ24pSg

description.plain:
Found You is the new single of Lil' Kim’s fifth studio album titled ‘9’. It’s featured with Yung Miami from the City Girls & O.T. Genasis.

The song was released on September 27, the 14th anniversary of her last album ‘The Naked Truth’.

songs.full_title: Auto Blanco by Lil' Kim
songs.title: Auto Blanco

description.plain: With the (somewhat predictable) announcement that Lil' Kim’s next album, 9, was being pushed back, she dropped this freestyle over Lil' Durk’s “No Auto Durk” (itself a remix of G Herbo’s “Never Cared”) to placate the fans. Resurrecting the Kimmy Blanco moniker, she delivers a mumble rap-like verse full of dark, threatening bars over a menacing bass-heavy beat, completely autotune-free, to let everyone know she’s still got it.

songs.full_title: Took Us a Break by Lil' Kim
songs.title: Took Us a Break

description.plain:
Allegedly titled “Money Burn”, Lil' Kim premiered the music video on October 11, 2017 at the Urban One’s Annual Blitz Showcase in New York City. She described the song as her “set up record” and announced that the lead single off her upcoming album would be released in January 2018.
On November 3, 2017, the single became available on iTunes, revealing its title “Took Us a Break”.

songs.full_title: Quiet by Lil' Kim (Ft. The Game)
songs.title: Quiet

description.plain: Here the Queen Bitch of Hip Hop takes the title ‘bitch’ literally, as she barks back at the haters, and rightfully so. By the time of release of The Naked Truth, it had been two years since Lil Kim left the music scene temporarily to focus on Fashion, Hollywood, and her crippling legal issues. All the while, other artists had been attacking Kim, and coming for her crown, and we all know Queen Bee ain’t letting that go down.

songs.full_title: Spell Check by Lil' Kim

description.plain:
The opening track on her 4th solo album, The Naked Truth is inspired by K. Solo’s “Spellbound”. In this song Lil' Kim spells out her rhymes while dissing 50 Cent and Junior M.A.F.I.A.

This first verse of the song is at the end of the music video for “Whoa”.

description.plain: You Are Not Alone is a track from Lil' Kim’s fifth studio album titled ‘9’. The song makes room for Lil’ Kim to jump right in and spit onto a wavering piano key and heavy percussive instrumental. It has an interesting structure with a single verse spanning the entire track.

songs.full_title: Warning by Lil' Kim
songs.title: Warning

description.plain:
“Warning” is a song by Lil Kim that was featured on her 2011 mixtape “Black Friday”

The song is also alternatively titled “Pissin On Em”

In this track Lil Kim creates a parody/mock/wack version of the original Nicki version, as well as throwing initial disses towards her. It counts as the second most significant diss track towards Nicki Minaj.

The track samples the original beat from “Did It On Em” by Nicki Minaj from her debut 2010 album “Pink Friday”.

Kim also makes witty references to other tracks by Nicki such as “Im The Best” and “Autobiography”.

songs.full_title: What's the Word by Lil' Kim
songs.title: What’s the Word

description.plain:
It is a “buzz” single released in 2002 to promote the release of her third album, La Bella Mafia.

Due to not having an official release, it peaked at #9 on the Bubbling Under R&B /Hip-Hop singles chart. It would later be included on the Japan edition of La Bella Mafia as a bonus track.

songs.full_title: Diamonds by Lil' Kim (Ft. Kelly Price)
songs.title: Diamonds

description.plain:
The song was intended for The Notorious K.I.M., however it was left unreleased due to clearance issues. Diana Ross, despite her friendship with Kim, refused the clearance of the sample of Muscles.

It is assumed that it is Kelly Price on the chorus/ad-libs, however this has never been confirmed.

songs.full_title: Last Day by Lil' Kim
songs.title: Last Day

description.plain:
“Last Day” is the last song on The Naked Truth. In the song Kim is talking about all of her achievements in the rap game and the legacy she’s gonna leave behind after her death.

The song is followed by a skit in which we hear a phonecall between Kim and her friend Monique “Mo Betta” Dopwell. She was one of Kim’s closest associates who supported Kim during her trial. Their conversation revolves around Kim’s trial and how dissapointed she is in her former bandmates of Junior M.A.F.I.A. who testified against her.

songs.full_title: The Queen by Lil' Kim (Ft. Diddy)
songs.title: The Queen

description.plain: Lil Kim wanted this song to be the lead single for her sophomore album The Notorious K.I.M. The record label didn’t agree with Kim and insisted on releasing “No Matter What They Say”. With time running out and not wanting her first week album sales to suffer, Kim agreed with her label to release the song. “The Queen” never made it on the album’s final track listing.

songs.full_title: Bad Girls by Lil' Kim (Ft. RuPaul)
songs.title: Bad Girls

description.plain:
-Was an unreleased song from The Notorious K.I.M. album that was supposed to be on the track list along with eleven other songs, but it was leaked before the album dropped so it had to be scrapped. The Queen Bee recorded twelve more tracks in three weeks, which were all successfully released when the album was dropped or out of her doing.
-The chorus samples Donna Summer’s song, ‘Bad Girls’ in which RuPaul takes Donna Summer’s part.
-The beat also has samples from Donna Summer’s song, ‘Bad Girls’.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HzxW4eu9heY

songs.full_title: This Is a Warning by Lil' Kim
songs.title: This Is a Warning

description.plain:
Lil Kim samples “A Woman’s Warning”, written and produced by R. Kelly himself, but wrote her own personal lyrics.

This song stands out in Kim’s discography because she sings in an R&B style, which is unusual for her.

During the time surrounding this album Kim had public beef with rappers Eve and Foxy Brown which may be who the song is directed at, among others.

songs.full_title: Makes No Sense by Lil' Kim (Ft. Tanya Stephens)
songs.title: Makes No Sense

description.plain:
“Makes No Sense” was a song intented to appear on Kim’s sophomore album The Notorious K.I.M. but leaked online months before the official release forcing Kim to scrap it.

The reggae infused bad bitch anthem features Jamaican recording artist Tanya Stephens. Kim’s love for Jamaican culture and Stephens' music was again present years later on Kim’s last studio album The Naked Truth where she sampled her song “Mi And Mi God” for her dancehall-infused “Durty.”

songs.full_title: If You Love Me by Lil' Kim
songs.title: If You Love Me

description.plain:
Lil Kim’s first and heavily anticipated track release of 2012, after she uploaded promotional posters via her Twitter account.

Released on Valentine’s Day, possibly to spite Nicki Minaj in their ongoing beef. Pink Friday: Roman Reloaded was due to be released on the same day until it was pushed back to 3 March.

songs.full_title: Fat PumPum by Lil' Kim (Ft. Vena E.)
songs.title: Fat PumPum

description.plain:
“Fat PumPum” is a song by American rapper Lil' Kim featuring Vena E. included on her fifth official studio album due to be released before the end of the year.

As suggested by the title the song is an island infused sex anthem with ‘'Pum Pum’‘ being the Jamaican term for the sexual female organ. The collaboration was announced on October 1st, 2019 during the reunion episode of Kim’s Reality Tv show Girls Cruise. As explained by Kim it was a last minute decision since both ladies became good friends while filming for the show. https://twitter.com/GirlsCruiseVH1/status/1178852135657717760

songs.full_title: Street Dreams by Lil' Kim (Ft. The Notorious B.I.G.)
songs.title: Street Dreams

description.plain:
“Street Dreams” is an unreleased song recorded during the sessions for Lil' Kim’s 1996 album, Hard Core. The Notorious B.I.G. provides background vocals throughout the song.

Lil' Kim later used this song’s instrumental, as well as some lyrics, on her November 1996 track “Big Momma Thang,” and the opening lyrics to the first verse appeared on October 1996’s “No Time”.

The chorus for the track plays off of the 1983 Eurythmics track “Sweet Dreams (Are Made Of This)”. Interestingly, fellow New York rapper Nas recorded his own track called “Street Dreams” that played off the song — like Kim’s, his track came out in 1996, so it’s unclear who recorded their version first.

description.plain:
An early version of Lil' Kim’s track “Queen Bitch” featured chorus vocals from Aaliyah, which were later scrapped in favor of a sample from Kim’s closing verse on the Junior M.A.F.I.A. song “Back Stabbers”.

Kim had previously worked with Aaliyah on Junior M.A.F.I.A’s “I Need You Tonight”.
